Her brother is a driver and provides transportation services for his passengers.
Rasoolan has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for the further expansion of her sewing business. With the loan she will buy another sewing machine and will hire an assistant. This will allow her to receive more orders and make more profit.
She has been in her business for 4 years and is very confident that an investment will help her to further improve it.
Note: “In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Rasoolan”.

loans.use: to buy another sewing machine

loans.name: Mwita

texts.en:
Mwita has witnessed a lot of growth in his business since he took his previous loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings. He used the loan to buy medicine for animals, syringes and needles. This helped him to work more efficiently.
His desire is to fully establish his business in five years.
Mwita has requested a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy vaccines.

loans.use: To buy vaccines

loans.name: Villamor

texts.en: Villamor owns and manages his corn field. He has been managing it for almost 20 years. According to him, he is able to earn about P30,000 per cropping season. Villamor's income goes to his family's daily needs, allowances, and school fees of his children, and some is used for the payment of electric bills. His funds are insufficient to maintain and buy some farm inputs for his business. So for this reason, he is asking for additional capital amounting to P27,000 to be used in buying farm inputs such as fertilizer, certified seeds, and insecticides for the maintenance of his business. Although Villamor encountered some difficulties in his farming business, he still believes that he could overcome all those things. He hopes that he can be a successful farmer someday through the help of his family members and through the financial assistance given to him. With this success in life, he could give a better education to his three children.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs such as fertilizer, certified seeds, and insecticides for maintenance of his business.

loans.name: Roeun

texts.en: Mrs. Roeun is now a 48-years-old, married woman who has been residing in Ornlong Veng district, Siem Reap province, Cambodia. Most of the people who live there prefer doing farming for their livelihoods to other careers. One among them, Roeun, is in the business of cultivating rice crops. She typically earns an income of $1.50 each day from this business. She is diligent in working because she wants to support her single child to join a university. Besides farming, Roeun is also skillful in making plastic kindling, which can be used by housewives to make fire for cooking. She has operated this business since 2010.  It can make additional profit for her family. Presently, she has run out of raw materials from her stock. Thus, she is looking for a loan from HKL and Kiva to purchase raw materials for making plastic kindling. She’ll be able to run this business continually through using this loan from lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials for making plastic kindling.

loans.name: Sabran's Group

texts.en:
Sabran is 45 years old, and sews clothes for her neighboring clients in order to share the financial burden with her husband. She is very skillful and has a good business sense. She receives regular orders every month which earns her a reasonable income. Sabran is the mother of two children, both of them are enrolled in local school and are getting their education.

Her husband is a milk seller. He operates his business from the shop from where he sells fresh quality milk to his customers at reasonable rates. Sabran has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business.  With the loan, he will buy milk in larger quantities for selling. He is very experienced in his business and operating it for the passed many years. Sabran is hopeful that a loan investment will be more productive for his business.

Note: In the photo, the lady holding a book (called Asasah Passbook) is Sabran.

loans.use: to buy milk for selling.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en: Jane is a single woman aged 30. She has been selling shoes for the last four years to make a living. She is also employed.  Her potential customers are passerbys and local residents. Jane has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenyan shillings to add stock of shoes for resale. In the next five years, she plans to establish a wholesale business.

loans.use: To add stock of shoes.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new beauty salon kit.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: Esther is a 35 years old married woman with no children. She has a business of selling beer in Yei South Sudan for five years. Esther requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beer. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase beer for sale.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en: Peter is a hardworking business man aged 49. He is married and blessed with three children and one of them is in school. He has been running a butcher shop for the last four years to support his family. He also practices dairy farming to supplement his income. In the next 5 years, he wants to expand his business. He is requesting for a loan of 100,000 Kenya shillings to open another butcher shop.

loans.use: To open another butcher shop.

loans.name: Baraka A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Baraka A Group in Western Kenya! Wycliffe is the facilitator of the Baraka A group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Wycliffe takes care of 12 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Wycliffe had a very good maize yield harvesting 19 bags on 3/4 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Wycliffe was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize on 3/4 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Wycliffe and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Wycliffe will educate his children and ensure food security.

In 2012, the members of Baraka A group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Wycliffe is pictured with his group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: John

texts.en: John is a hardworking business man aged 46. For the last year, he has been running a greengrocer's to make a living. Previously, he was operating a retail shop. In the next 5 years, he plans to manage a wholesale business. John has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenya shillings to buy vegetables and fruits for resale.

loans.use: To buy vegetables and fruits.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is married and blessed with three children. He describes himself as a hardworking business man. He has been selling  clothes for the last six years to support his family. He also runs a greengrocery for more income. 

Peter has requested a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy carrots and potatoes for resale. In the next 5 years, he plans to buy a piece of land. Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has been able to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To buy carrots and potatoes.

loans.name: Chamroeun

texts.en: Chamroeun is 42 years old and the father of five children. He has been earning a living as a carpenter for 20 years. He also catches fish to feed his family and generate additional income. His children also help him with carpentry and fishing work. This is his first loan with VisionFund. He is requesting a loan to buy wood for his carpentry work, so as to increase his stock and earn more income to feed his family and build some savings to expand his business.

loans.use: to buy wood to increase his stocks

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Majengo Group

texts.en:
Receive greetings from Majengo Group in Western Kenya! Beatrice is the facilitator of the Majengo group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Beatrice takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Beatrice had a very good maize yield harvesting 15 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Beatrice was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Beatrice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Beatrice will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Majengo group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

Beatrice is pictured with her group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Om

texts.en:
Mr. Om, 31, is a loving father of two single children. He lives in Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham province. As shown in the picture, Mr. Om and his wife are working with their rice husking machine under a house. This business activity earns him a good profit because there are many villagers who come to use his services, especially after their harvesting season. This couple is quite busy with farming during the rainy season but in the dry season there will be a lot of work to do as well. Mr. Om hopes to update his living conditions in the near future, so he has made many plans for his family businesses. 

Now Om is seeking a loan from HKL, one of Kiva’s partners, to buy a plowing machine. This tool can be used on his own farmland. Moreover, it will make more profit for the family if his neighbors and other villagers want to rent this machine. Om is very thankful to all Kiva’s funders who support his business.

loans.use: to buy a plowing machine.

loans.name: Ziyad

texts.ru:
Ziyad yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli goroda seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey semyoy. On jenat i imeyet 2 detey. Ziyad 57 let. 
Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit zapchasti dlya pochinki mashini. Uje 15 let kak rabotayet shoferom, ranshe on rabotal shoferom v firme seychas on uje rabotayet taxistom.
texts.en: Ziyad is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from the town of Fuzuli and now lives with his family in the Fuzuli region.  He is married and has two children.  Ziayd is 57 years old.  Currently, he needs 2000 AZN to buy spare parts and repair his car.  He has been working as a driver for 15 years, previously worked as a driver in a company and now works as a taxi driver.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and repair his car

loans.name: Tho

texts.en: Tho is 33 years old and a widower. He has been farming on his rice field for almost 10 years to make a living. He also raises pigs to generate additional income. He has been with VisionFund for 3 years. Tho completely repaid his loans from VisionFund. Now he is applying for a fourth loan to grow rice and raise pigs. This loan will enable him to harvest more rice and increase his piglets and earn more income to expand his business.

loans.use: to grow rice and raise pigs.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Khursheed's Group

texts.en:
Khursheed has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for further expansion of her seat-cover making business. She prepares motorbike and bicycle seat covers and is an expert in her work. With the loan she will buy raw materials such as leather and thread in larger quantity to be able to prepare better quality seat covers.

She is very experienced in her work and has been operating her business for many years. She is confident that a loan investment will help her expand her business further.

She is a widow and has two sons and a daughter. After the death of her husband, she worked very hard to raise her children. All of her children have studied till the intermediate level and now do different kind of work to financially contribute to the family.

loans.use: to buy thread and leather for seat-cover making business

loans.name: Ly

texts.en: Ly is a 43-year-old mother of two children and she is a widow. For the last 25 years, she has been earning a living by running a grocery store in the front yard of her house. She sells bread, cake, drinking water, fruit, etc. To support her family, she also plants cassava to generate additional income. This is her first loan with VisionFund. She wants to buy grocery stock and plant cassava. This loan will help her to increase her grocery stock and harvest more cassava which will enable her to earn more income to feed her family and build up some savings for her children.

loans.use: to buy grocery stock and plant cassava.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Davud

texts.ru: On jenat i imeyet 2 detey. Davud 43 qoda. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom on pereselenec iz Fuzuli goroda seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey jenoy i detmi. Davud uje 7 let kak zanimayetsya skotovodstvom i razvodit korov. Davud ochen lubit jivotnix a takje svoyu rabotu. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya uvelichesniya kolichestva skota.
texts.en: Davud is married and has two children.  He is 43 years old.  He is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from the town of Fuzuli and now lives with his wife and children in the Fuzuli region.  Davud has been involved in animal husbandry for seven years and breeds cattle.  He loves his animals and his work.  Currently, Davud needs 2000 AZN to buy cattle in order to increase his livestock quantity.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy perfumes, sanitary pads, and raw materials to make floor polish.

loans.name: Yazan

texts.en: Yazan is 32 years old and he is a tailor. He is requesting a loan for $2,500 from FATEN, which he will use to purchase a new sewing machine and make some repairs to the shop, such as painting and installing tiles. These upgrades will allow him to increase his productivity and income so his living conditions are improved.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine and make repairs to the tailoring shop.

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mao is 45 years old, married, and has four children. He runs a business buying recycled materials, which he sells to merchants. Mao has been in this business for 10 years. He buys beer cans, steel, etc. To better feed his family, he plants cassava and rubber trees. He also works for others for additional income. 

Mao is requesting his second loan with VisionFund, which he will use to buy recycled materials for his business. He completely repaid his first loan. With this loan, he hopes to increase his stock, earn more income to feed his family, and build his savings for his children and the future.

loans.use: to purchase recycled materials for resale.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes, shoes, vases and curtains.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy chicken feed.

loans.name: Choeun

texts.en:
Choeun is widowed with one child. She is 52 years old. 

She plants cassava. To better support her family, she also makes fried bananas to generate additional income. She has been planting cassava for eight years. 

This is her second loan with VisionFund. She is requesting a loan to plant more cassava. With this loan, she hopes to grow more cassava, which will enable her to generate more income to better feed her family and improve her business.

loans.use: to plant cassava.

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Ponhea Krek district

loans.name: Nasreen's Group

texts.en:
Nasreen is 53 year old, an embroidery expert who shares the financial burden with her husband by doing decorative embroidery. She also has an animal selling business. She buys goats and sheep in their younger age, raises them and sells at a profit to butchers.

Her husband is a milk seller. He operates his business from the shop and offers good rates to his customers.

Nasreen is the mother of three sons and a daughter. Her sons have businesses of selling fruits and vegetables while her daughter is a seamstress.

Nasreen has applied for a loan loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her eldest son’s business. With the loan he will buy vegetables and fruits of fresh quality that will allow him to increase his profits and sales.

He has been operating his business for many years and Nasreen is hopeful that an investment will help him make more money from it.

loans.use: to buy fruits and vegetables for selling.

loans.name: Gurshad

texts.ru: Gurshad 11 let nazad nachal zanimatsya skotovodstvom i razvodit ovec. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit ovec. On tak je iz shersti ovec delayet jeleti i podstilki i prodayet ix. Gurshad jenat i imeyet 3 detey kotoriye pomogayut inogda yemu po rabote. On yavlyayetsya IDP personom pereselenec iz Fuzuli goroda seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste s semyoy. Gurshad 58 let.
texts.en: Gurshad started his animal husbandry business and breeding sheep 11 years ago.  Currently, he needs 2000 AZN to buy sheep.  He also makes vests and covers from the wool and sells them.  Gurshad is married and has three children, who sometimes help him with the work.  He is an IDP (Internally Displaced Person) from the town of Fuzuli and now lives with his family in the Fuzuli region.  Gurshad is 58 years old.

loans.use: to purchase sheep

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy 10 duvets.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy weaves, hair chemicals and jewelry.

loans.name: Ingizar

texts.en:
Ingizar is from the village of Kharajalari in the Kartli region. She is 62 years old and lives with her family: her husband, Javanshir; their 36-year-old son; their daughter-in-law, and their 12-year-old granddaughter, who goes to school.

Ingizar and her husband earn a living through vegetable growing. They own agricultural land with a total area of 1,500 sq. meters. The family grows greens on the land. Ingizar sells harvested greens in Tbilisi, the capital city of the country. Ingizar’s son is a worker in the village. The total average monthly income of the family is 1,200 GEL.  

Ingizar requested credit for diversifying the family’s agricultural activities. She plans to purchase calves. She will feed them during winter months and sell for a higher price in spring. The family will have more income. Ingizar plans to make some savings from the earned profit, as she wants to renovate the family house in the nearest future.

loans.use: to purchase calves.

loans.name: Sango A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Sango A Group in Western Kenya! Francis is the facilitator of the Sango A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Francis takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to educate his children, and to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the  2011 season, Francis had a very good maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Francis was only able to harvest 10 bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Francis and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Francis will educate his children and ensure food security for his family. 

In 2012, the members of Sango A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

He is pictured in the photograph with his group members.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Silvester

texts.en:
Silvester used his previous loan to buy maize flour, sugar and cooking fat. His business improved.  

His desire is to expand his business into wholesale in the future. He dreams of buying a vehicle in five years.

Silvester has requested 110,000 KES to buy cereals, maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking fat.

loans.use: To buy cereals, maize flour, sugar, rice and cooking fat.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora is a young Palestinian woman. She is a graphic designer. She wants to purchase a new laptop to use for designing advertisements using different programs. But she hasn't enough money, so she needs to take a loan from FATEN. 

When Nora gets the loan, she will be able to purchase a new laptop to improve her work and make more designs to sell. This will increase her income and improve her living conditions.

loans.use: To purchase a new laptop for work.

loans.name: Nabangala Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Nabangala Group in Western Kenya! Patrick is the facilitator of the Nabangala group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Patrick takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Patrick had a very good maize yield harvesting 22 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Patrick was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Patrick and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Patrick will educate his children, ensure food security for his family, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Nabangala group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Upendo Group

texts.en:
Judith is the facilitator of Upendo group. Judith and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Judith takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Judith had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Judith was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on ½  acres of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Judith and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Judith will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Upendo group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Patrick

texts.en:
Patrick is 41 years old and single. To earn a living, he does photography. He has been in the business for three years and has employed one person.  

Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has become more financially stable. This is because he has improved his business with his previous loan from Faulu Kenya.

Patrick hopes to expand his business in the future. He has requested a loan of 60,000 KES to rent a business premise.

loans.use: To rent a business premise.

loans.name: Huruma B Group

texts.en:
Solomon is the facilitator of Huruma B group. Solomon and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Solomon takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season,Solomon had an excellent maize yield harvesting 26 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Solomon was only able to harvest 12 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Solomon and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Solomon will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Huruma B group will each plant maize plots on between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is 29 years old, is married and has a three-year-old child.  He has been doing photography for eleven years and has employed one person.  Since he joined Faulu Kenya, he has improved his business because he has been trained in business management skills. He hopes to expand his business so that he can become more financially stable. 

Michael has requested for a loan of 20,000 Kenya shillings to buy a camera.

loans.use: To buy a camera

loans.name: Nyash Group

texts.en:
Philomina is a hardworking woman aged 39. She is married with five children aged 19, 15, 10 and twins aged 7. They all attend school. She also takes responsibility for one further dependent.

Philomina makes peanut butter and has one peanut butter-making machine.  Currently, she has no employees. She has been in business for the past two years now. Philomina is requesting for a loan from Microking Finance  to purchase nuts from the communal farmers in Mvuma to make peanut butter for sale. The main challenge is that groundnuts are very expensive and seasonal. Also there is an increasing number of people who are making peanut butter. She sees herself with five peanut butter-making machines, employees and also having her own grinding mill for maize in the next five years.

This loan should enable her to pay fees for her children and improve their standard of living.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts from communal farmers in Mvuma

loans.name: Elias

texts.en: Elias is 27-year-old Lebanese single man living with his parents and two siblings, both of whom are working. In 2007, he opened a barbershop in his town after seeing a need for such service in the region.  He has 12 years of experience working in this field; he learned this occupation as a young man. Today, he is requesting to borrow $400 from Kiva Partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase new shaving tools and other products for his barbershop. In the future, he plans to open a new branch of his shop.

loans.use: To purchase new shaving tools and other products for his barbershop

loans.name: Nenisa

texts.en: Nenisa is a 35-year-old, married woman who has four children, one is in school. She has had a food stall in Yei, South Sudan for three years. Nenisa requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase tomatoes and onions. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes and onions for sale

loans.name: Josphine

texts.en: Josphine is 23 years old and single. She runs a retail shop so as to earn a living. She has been in the business for 5 years. Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Josphine has improved her business because she has been trained in business management skills. Josphine hopes to own a supermarket in 5 years. She wants to start a business of selling gas cylinders. Hence, she has requested a loan of 100,000 KES to buy gas cylinders.

loans.use: to buy gas cylinders

loans.name: Manana

texts.en:
Manana lives in the village of Lemshveniera, Kartli Region. She is 47 years old, married and lives with her family: husband Melori, 3 daughters (24, 18, 14 years old) and 12-year-old son. The 3 younger children go to school.

Manana and Melori earn a living through the family agricultural business. They have 17 cows and 4 calves. Manana produces traditional Georgian cheese and sells it to local dairy product retailers. Melori has a tractor and uses it for tilling and moving neighbors’ plots. Total average income of the family is 1,100 GEL per month. 

Manana requested credit for purchasing calves and hay for domestic animals. She will raise calves during winter months and sell grown calves for higher price in spring. It will increase their income and the family members will be able to improve living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase calves

loans.name: Lutaso Youth Group

texts.en:
Carolyne is the facilitator of Lutaso youth group. Carolyne and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Carolyne takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Carolyne had a very good maize yield harvesting 26 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Carolyne was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Carolyne and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance

With income from maize sales, Carolyne will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing

In 2012, the members of Lutaso youth group will each plant maize plots on between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 24 years old, single and lives with his parents and two siblings. In 2000, he opened a coffee shop in his town, and was careful to pick an excellent location where lots of people come to meet. On the side, he also works as a taxi driver, transporting students around town. He is applying for a loan for $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen to buy a generator for his business and a motorcycle which he will use to make deliveries. His goal for the future is to continue expanding his business.

loans.use: to buy a generator and a motorcycle.

loans.name: Mahiyaddin

texts.ru: Mahiyaddin jenat i imeyet 2 detey. On zanimayetsya skotovodstvom uje 9 let i razvodit korov. Mahiyaddin yavlyayetsya IDP personom, pereselenec iz Fuzuli goroda seychas projivayet v Fuzuli regione vmeste so svoyey lubimoy jenoy i detmi. Seychas on nujdayetsya v 2000 AZN chtobi kupit korovi dlya uvelicheniya kolichestva dlya pereprodaji. Ranshe on razvodil ovec no potom nachal razvodit korov.
texts.en: Mahiyaddin is married and has two children. He has been in animal farming for nine years already. He breeds cattle. Mahiyaddin is an Internallly Displaced Person from the town of Fuzuli now living in the region of Fuzuli together with his beloved wife and children. At present he needs 2000 AZN in order to buy cattle to expand his sales volume. He used to breed sheep but later on he started breeding cattle.

loans.use: to buy cattle

loans.name: Jacinta

texts.en: Jacinta is a 57-year-old widow with nine children between the ages of 18 and 35.  To earn a living, she does dairy farming.  She has been in business for ten years. In addition, she grows potatoes, tomatoes and coffee for commercial use. She works hard in her business in order to provide for her family.  Jacinta hopes to practice large-scale farming in five years.  She has requested a loan of 100,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a cow and animal feed as well as to construct a cowshed.

loans.use: to buy a cow and animal feed as well as to construct a cowshed.

loans.name: Loice

texts.en: Loice is 34 years, married and has two children, neither of whom is yet in school. She earns a living by selling food in her town, Yei, South Sudan. She is applying for a loan from BRAC South Sudan to buy beans and rice. She will use the extra income made possible by this loan to begin building a house for her family.

loans.use: to buy beans, maize flour and rice to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Buyanyi Youth Group

texts.en:
Annah is the facilitator of Buyanyi youth group. Annah and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Annah takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Annah had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on 3/4 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Annah was only able to harvest 3  bags of maize on 3/4  acres of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Annah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Annah will educate her children, build a house, and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Buyanyi youth group will each plant maize plots on between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jaribu B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Jaribu B Group in Western Kenya! Florence is the facilitator of the Jaribu B group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Florence takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Florence had an good maize yield harvesting 6 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Florence was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1/2 an acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Florence and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Florence will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in an income-generating activity.

In 2012, the members of Jaribu B group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Korokoro M.s.h.g Group

texts.en:
Kituyi is the facilitator of Korokoro M.S.H group. Kituyi and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Kituyi takes care of 11 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Kituyi had an excellent maize yield harvesting 22 bags on 1  acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Kituyi was only able to harvest 7 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Kituyi and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Kituyi will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Korokoro M.S.H group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mohamad Hussein

texts.en: M. Hussein is 18 years old and lives at home with his parents and one sibling. Unlike other people his age, he wasn’t able to continue his education because of his parent’s poverty. He is taking responsibility for his life and has started to work on his own. Today, he is the proud owner of a motorcycle repair shop. He is applying for a loan for $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen to buy mechanical supplies for his business so that he can improve his ability to serve his customers. In the future, he plans to continue to expand his business by buying more spare parts.

loans.use: to buy supplies for his motorcycle repair shop.

loans.name: Natela

texts.en: Natela is 47 years old and lives in the Gardabani, Kartli region of Georgia with her husband Elvar and 23-year-old son. Elvar works as teacher in a local school, and the entire family works on the family's farm, a three hectare plot of land where they grow broom. Natela uses the crop to make brooms, which she sells in her nation's capital, Tbilisi. The family earns about 1,100 Laris a month. Natela is applying for this loan to hire seasonal help, which will allow her to increase the size of her crop and, with it, her family's income.

loans.use: to hire seasonal help to work on her farm.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase more adenga fabric and also diversify into bedspreads.

loans.name: Embako Group

texts.en:
Caro is the facilitator of Embako group. Caro and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Caro takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Caro had a good maize yield harvesting 12  bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Caro was only able to harvest 3  bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Caro and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Caro will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Embako group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is a 49 years old, married, and has four children.  He lives in Lebanon. Mostafa has owned a mobile phone shop for the past two years. He is well known in his village and sells high-quality items. Since 2004, Mostafa has been the mayor of his town. 

Mostafa is requesting a loan for $1,200 from Ameen s.a.l., which he will use to increase his merchandise selection of new mobile phones and accessories, thereby increasing his sales and his income.

loans.use: to increase his merchandise selection of new mobile phones and accessories.

loans.name: Mambo Leo A Group

Greetings from Mambo Leo A Group in Western Kenya! Richard is the facilitator of the Mambo Leo A SHG group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Richard takes care of 10 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Richard had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Richard was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Richard  and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Richard will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mambo Leo A SHG group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is 32 years old, married and lives in Lebanon with his wife and three school-aged children. Since 1999, he has been the owner of an aluminum factory. His wife helps contribute to the family's income by working as a teacher. Mohamad is applying for a loan for $1,200 from Kiva partner Ameenl to upgrade his shop's electrical generator. In the future, he plans to expand his business into other areas.

loans.use: to upgrade his shop's generator.

Before joining One Acre Fund, Reuben was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Reuben and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. With income from maize sales, Reuben will educate his child, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Sinani S.H.G group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Dena

texts.en: Dena is a 27-year-old woman. Her husband is employed by a company that pays him a decent salary. Dena has a grocery store near her house. She wants to purchase some groceries to sell, but the amount of money she has isn't enough to pay for what she needs. She is taking a loan of 2,000 USD from FATEN. When Dena gets the loan, she will be able to purchase more groceries and have more variety of goods to sell. This will enable her to attract more customers and increase her sales in order to increase her income. Dena is a conservative woman, so her husband is photographed here instead of her.

loans.use: To purchase groceries for resale

loans.name: Simana W.g A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Simana W. Group A in Western Kenya! Judith is the facilitator of Simana W. group A. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Judith takes care of one child at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Judith had a very good maize yield harvesting 5 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Judith was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Judith and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. With income from maize sales, Judith will educate her child, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Simana W group A will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy 7 television sets and 5 DVDs from Botswana to resell

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim is a 44-year-old married Lebanese man who lives with his wife and three children. His children are still attending school. He is the main income provider of the family. Ibrahim is doing his best to satisfy his family's needs. He has been working as a glazier for the past 21 years and opened his own shop three years ago. Today, he’s requesting to borrow 1,200 USD from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase new glass supplies and mirrors. He really believes that this Kiva loan will increase his productivity by a large percentage. In the future, he plans to enlarge his business operation.

loans.use: To purchase new glass supplies and mirrors

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy cosmetics and jewellery for resale

loans.name: Milembe Wg A Group

texts.en:

Pamela  takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Pamela had a very good maize yield harvesting 7 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Pamela was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Pamela  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Pamela will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Ludiya

texts.en:
Ludiya is 33 year old and married wirh four children, none of them in school. She has had a business selling charcoal in Yei South Sudan for four years.
Ludiya requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay the expenses to finish work on her house.

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a 19-year-old single man. He’s from Lebanon and lives with one parent, a sibling and a cousin. Regardless of his young age, he was eager to start his own business as a plumber. He has been involved in this type of business for the past three years. He works on his own and his parents are really proud of him. Today, he is asking for a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase additional plumbing tools and supplies. This will facilitate his business operations, especially in installing faucets, tubes, pipes etc. In the future, he plans to open his own, complete plumbing business.

loans.use: To purchase additional plumbing tools and supplies

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: Juliana is 31 years old and a single mother of one. She runs a tailoring business to earn a living. She has been in the business for five years and has employed one person to assist her in her tasks. She also sells cereals and does farming for extra income. Juliana hopes to expand her business. She needs a loan of 100,000 kenya shillings to buy cereals.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Likuche Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Likuche Group in Western Kenya! George is the facilitator of Likuche group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

George takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, George had a good maize yield harvesting 8 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, George was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to George and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, George will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Likuche group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Twigarukire Group

texts.fr:
Médiatrice est une commerçante âgée de 42ans qui habite la localité de Bwoga de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce de produits alimentaires (haricots, riz, huile végétale…) depuis 5 ans. Elle est aussi cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Elle est mariée et mère de 8enfants dont 6étudient. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 100,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités de produits alimentaires (haricots, riz, huile végétale…)  à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Twigarukire»
texts.en:
Médiatrice is a 42-year-old merchant who lives in the town of Bwoga, in the Gitega province, in the center of the country.  She has been buying and selling grocery products (beans, rice, vegetable oil) for five years.  She is also a farmer.  She attended school up to the sixth year of primary school.  She is married and the mother of eight children, six of whom attend school.
The Kiva loan of 100,000 Burundi francs will increase her capital, allowing her to buy large quantities of items (beans, rice, vegetable oil) to sell in order to make large profits. 
She is a member of the “Twigarukire” community group.

loans.use: to increase her capital, allowing her to buy large quantities of items (beans, rice, vegetable oil) to sell in order to make large profits.

loans.name: Eva

texts.en:
Eva is 40 years old and married woman with five children, two of them in school. She has had a business selling fish in Yei, South Sudan for six years.
Eva requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase fish. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a concrete house in future.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Mostafa

texts.en:
Mostafa is 40 years old  and single.  He lives in Lebanon with his parents. He and his father work to cover their expenses and improve the family's standard of living, especially as Mostafa does not have a family of his own. 

Mostafa opened his own minimarket in 2002 and makes a good income. He is requesting a loan for $700 Ameen s.a.l, which he will use to increase his store's inventory of groceries, dairy products, and daily products. This loan will help him increase his revenues by 15%. In the future, he plans to expand his business even further.

loans.use: to increase his store's inventory of groceries, dairy products, and daily products.

loans.name: Ndareti S.h.g Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Ndareti S.H Group in Western Kenya! Mary is the facilitator of the Ndareti S.H group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Mary takes care of nine children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Mary had a good maize yield harvesting 6 bags on 0.5 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Mary was only able to harvest 1.5 bags of maize on 0.5 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mary and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Mary will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Ndareti S.H group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mikhonge A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Mikhonge A Group in Western Kenya! It is headed by Annah as the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Annah takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Annah had a very good maize yield harvesting 13 bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Annah was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Annah and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Annah will invest in livestock rearing and ensure food security for her family. 

In 2012, the members of Mikhonge A group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

She is pictured with her group members in the photograph.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Benard

texts.en:
Benard is 26 years old, married, and has one child. For the last two years, he has been selling clothes to support his family. His potential customers are passersby and local residents. 

Benard is requesting a loan for 20,000 Kenya shillings, which he will use to add stock of skirts and blouses to sell. In the next five years, he plans to establish a wholesale business. He dreams of becoming more financially stable in future.

loans.use: to add stock of skirts and blouses.

loans.name: Korokoro S.h.g B Group

texts.en:
Naloba is the facilitator of Korokoro S.H.G.B. group. Naloba and his group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Naloba and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Naloba had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Naloba was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With income from maize sales, Naloba will invest in livestock rearing and will also build a house. 

In 2012, the members of Korokoro S.H.G.B. group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 26 years old. She is a married woman with two children, both of whom are in school. She has had a business of selling maize and sugar in Yei, South Sudan, for four years.

Rose requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase sugar. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase sugar for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy raw materials like fleece and wool.

loans.name: Hoda

texts.en: Hoda is a 44-year-old Lebanese married woman. She lives with her four children. Her husband is working outside the country and is barely helping her with the family expenses because of his limited income. That was the motive for her to start her own business working in producing handicrafts, needlework, embroidery, etc. in order to improve the family's financial situation. She has been working in this domain for the past 15 years; her work is based at her home. Additionally, she has given private lessons since 2004. Today, she’s asking to borrow $800 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to buy products for her handmade work. In the future, she plans to open her own shop.

loans.use: to buy products for her handmade work.

loans.name: Tujijure 2 Group

texts.fr:
Marie est une commerçante âgée de 48ans qui habite la localité de Rutoki de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce d’articles divers de boutique (haricots, riz, sucre, savons, biscuits…) depuis 5 ans. Elle est aussi cultivatrice. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire. Elle est mariée a Paul ; un tailleur et ont ensemble  7 enfants dont 5 étudient. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 200,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités d’articles divers de boutique (haricots, riz, sucre, savons, biscuits…)  à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Tujijure II»
texts.en:
Marie is a 48-year-old merchant who lives in the town of Rutoki in the province of Gitega in the center of the country.  She has been buying and selling various items (beans, rice, sugar, soaps, cookies) for five years.  She is also a farmer. She attended school up to the sixth year of primary school.  She is married to Paul, a tailor, and they have seven children together, five of whom attend school.

The Kiva loan of 200,000 Burundi francs will increase her capital, allowing her to buy large quantities of items (beans, rice, sugar, soap, cookies) to sell in order to earn a large profit. 

She is a member of the community group “Tujijure II”.

loans.use: to increase her capital, allowing her to buy large quantities of items (beans, rice, sugar, soap, cookies) to sell in order to earn a large profit.

loans.name: Wissam

texts.en: Wissam is a 39-year-old Lebanese married woman living with her husband and one school-aged child. She helps her husband, who works as an employee in a local company, with the household expenses. As for her, Wissam has been working as a tailor for the past 15 years and has owned her shop since 2003. She has gained a good number of customers who ask for her services. Today, she’s looking to borrow $1,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to enlarge her business and increase her productivity by purchasing additional tailoring tools and supplies. She estimates that the loan will help her increase her profits by 10 percent.

loans.use: to purchase additional tailoring tools and supplies.

loans.name: Enock

texts.en: Enock is a hardworking business man who is 29 years old. He is married and blessed with one child. For two years, he has been selling rubber stamps to make a living. Previously, he was a farmer. He has requested a loan of 30,000 KES to buy a rubber-stamp engraving machine. In the next five years, he wants to establish his own company.

loans.use: to buy a rubber-stamp engraving machine.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a 28-year-old married woman has three children, one of whom is in school. She has had a business selling charcoal in Yei, South Sudan, for four years. Betty requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Sisimukha Group

texts.en:
Gladys is the facilitator of the Sisimukha loan group. Gladys and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Gladys takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund's prices, to ensure food security for her family, and later to educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Gladys had a very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Gladys was only able to harvest three and a half bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Gladys and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Gladys will educate her children, build a house, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of the Sisimukha group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to add stock of clothes and to renovate his business premises.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Lucia from Gweru. Lucia is married with four children, two of whom are attending school. She runs a retail business selling kitchenware. The business has been in operation for five years.

She says the main challenge she faces is competition. Lucia has requested a loan of $1,200 to buy more kitchenware for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to look after her extended family members. In the future, Lucia plans to open another shop.

loans.use: to buy kitchenware stock for resale.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en: Zeinab is a 26-year-old Lebanese married woman. She lives with her husband and two children who are still attending school. Zeinab and her husband find it really hard to cover their expenses, especially with the heavy costs of life they are facing. Her husband has owned a cattle farm since 1995 and she has owned a small shop since 2009 where she sells artisan products, gifts and gadgets. Today, she’s asking for a loan of $2,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase more merchandise to add to her shop. She states that these purchases will increase her sales and consequently her income.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to add to her shop.

loans.name: Siata S.h.g Group

texts.en:
Mary is the facilitator of the Siata S.H.G. group. Mary and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Mary takes care of four children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to have access to One Acre Fund's low prices, to ensure food security for her family, and, later, to educate them. In the 2011 season, Mary had a good maize yield harvesting eight bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Mary was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mary and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Mary will educate her children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Siata S.H.G. group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Sosio Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Sosio Group in Western Kenya! Gilbert is the facilitator of the Sosio group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Gilbert takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Gilbert had an excellent maize yield harvesting 15 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Gilbert was only able to harvest five bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Gilbert and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input (such as fertilizer and seed) supply, credit, and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Gilbert will educate his children, ensure food security for his family, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Sosio group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Miriam

texts.en: Miriam is a single woman who is 39 years old. She has been running a butcher shop for the last five years to make a living. Her potential customers are the local residents. In the next five years, she wants to expand her business. Miriam has requested a loan of 40,000 KES to buy a weighing machine. Thanks to Faulu Kenya, she has become more financially stable.

loans.use: to buy a weighing machine.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad, a 32-year-old Lebanese single man living with one parent and three siblings, works with his siblings in order to improve the family’s standard of living. He began to work as a freelance painter in 2005 and is very loyal to his customers. Now requesting a loan of $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase painting equipment to start a new project, in the future Mohamad plans to open his own paint shop.

loans.use: to purchase painting equipment to start a new painting project.

loans.name: Reyda

texts.en: Reyda, a 30-year-old married woman with three children, two of whom are in school, has had a grocery store in Yei South Sudan for five years. Requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase maize flour and cassava flour, Reyda will use the extra income arising from it to build a very big shop for her business expansion in the future.

loans.use: to purchase maize flour and cassava flour to sell.

loans.name: Dzimbabwe Group

texts.en:
Janet, a 39-year-old married mother of five children, four of whom attend school, sells groceries in Harare, the capital city of Zimbabwe. In business for five years, her main challenges are price increases and competition.

Janet has requested a loan of $400.00 to buy groceries for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the well-being of her family, and in the future she plans to open a giant retail shop.

loans.use: to buy grocery stocks.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy, a determined 37-year-old married mother of two children, both of whom attend school, has been selling clothes to support her family for the last three years. She employs one person to help her to manage her enterprise which has done so well because of Lucy's good reputation amongst her customers. 

Since she joined Faulu Kenya, Lucy has been able to access loans to boost her business, and she is now requesting a new one for 50,000 Kenya shillings to purchase a new stock of clothes for resale. In the next five years, she wants to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Salah

texts.en: Salah is a 57-year-old Lebanese man who lives with his wife. Unfortunately, he did not have kids, but this was not a reason for him to become dispirited. Despite his older age, he works hard to support his wife. Salah has 41 years of experience working as a hairdresser and opened his own beauty salon in 1975. Today, he’s asking for a loan of $3,000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to redesign the interior of his shop. In the future, he plans to hire a full-time employee to work on his behalf.

loans.use: to redesign the interior of his shop

loans.name: Inua A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Inua A Group in Western Kenya! Abraham is the facilitator of the Inua A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Abraham takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to the better terms of loan payment with the firm, to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds, and to ensure food security for his family. In the 2011 season, Abraham had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Abraham was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Abraham and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input (such as fertilizer and seed) supply, credit, and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Abraham will increase his farming area and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Inua A group will each plant between three fourths and one acre of maize. 

He is pictured in the photograph above.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Tariro Group

texts.en: This is 29-year-old Abigal from Harare, the capital of Zimbabwe. She is married with four children. One is still in school. She also looks after two other dependents. She runs a business selling airtime. The business has been in operation for two years. Abigal says the main challenge she faces is stiff competition. She has requested a loan of $400 to purchase more airtime for resale. Abigal says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to improve the social well-being of her family. In the future she plans to be a wholesale airtime vendor.

loans.use: to buy airtime for resale

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 38-year-old married woman who has seven children, six of whom are in school. She has had a food stall business in Yei, South Sudan for six years.

Jane requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase beans, sugar, and rice. She will use her extra income to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase beans, sugar, and rice for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy clothes and shoes for sale.

loans.name: Mikhonge B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Mikhonge B Group in Western Kenya! Charles is the facilitator of the Mikhonge B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Charles takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Charles had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Charles was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Charles and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

With income from maize sales, Charles will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Mikhonge B group will each plant between ½ and one acre of maize. 

He is pictured in the photograph above.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mohamad

texts.en: Mohamad is a 37-year-old Lebanese married man living with his wife and two school-aged children.  He really works hard as he is the main income provider for his family. He has 17 years of experience working in the construction field, specializing in completing gypsum and painting work. Today, he’s requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to purchase a new electrical generator in order to improve his business and make his work much easier to perform. In the future, he seeks to open his own construction office.

loans.use: buy a generator for his construction business

loans.name: Njete Farmers Group

texts.en:
Simon is the facilitator of Njete farmers group. Simon and his group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Simon and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance. 

Simon takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to have access to One Acre Fund's low prices, to ensure food security for his family, and, later, to educate them. In the 2011 season, Simon had an excellent maize yield harvesting eight bags on three quarters of an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Simon was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With income from maize sales, Simon will educate his children, build a house and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Njete farmers group will each plant maize plots between ½ and one acre of land. 

The person standing on the far left of the photo is the field officer.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter used his previous loan to buy scrap metals, files and flax.  He was able to make more metallic doors and window frames from the raw materials (scrap metals) that he bought with the loan.  Since then, his business has improved, and hence also his living standards.

Peter hopes to become more financially stable in the future. He has requested a loan of 10,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a welding machine.

loans.use: buy a welding machine

loans.name: Silina

texts.en:
Silina is 26 years old.  She is a married woman and has five children, three of them are in school.  She has had food stall business in Yei, South Sudan,  for four years.

Silina requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase onions and tomatoes.  She will use her extra income to build a house in the future.

loans.use: buy tomatoes and onions for her food stall

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more chickens and chicken feeds

loans.name: Kitabani A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kitabani A Group in Western Kenya! Everline is the facilitator of the Kitabani A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Everline takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Everline had a very good maize yield harvesting seven bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Everline was only able to harvest three bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Everline and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Everline will educate her children and invest in livestock.

In 2012, the members of Kitabani A group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

She is pictured in the photograph with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yagamahoro Group

texts.fr:
Anastasie est une commerçante âgée de 33ans qui habite la localité de Kibimba de la Province de Gitega au centre du pays. Elle fait le commerce d’articles divers de boutique (haricots, riz, sucre, savons, biscuits, huile de palme…) depuis 4 ans. Elle faisait le commerce de bananes avant de commencer cette activité. Elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 5e année primaire. Elle est mariée a Jérôme ; un commerçant des articles de boutique ; et ont ensemble  5 enfants dont 3 étudient. 
 Le crédit Kiva  de 300,000 francs burundais qu’elle obtient lui permet d’augmenter son capital pour acheter de grandes quantités d’articles divers de boutique (haricots, riz, sucre, savons, biscuits, huile de palme…)  à revendre  afin de réaliser de grands bénéfices. 

Elle est membre  du groupe  communautaire« Yagamahoro»
texts.en:
Anastasie is a 33-year-old merchant who lives in the town of Kibimba in Gitega Province, in the middle of the country. She has been doing commerce in a variety of store goods (beans, rice, sugar, soaps, cookies, palm oil...) for four year. She used to deal in bananas before beginning her current business. 

Anastasie attended school and reached the 5th grade. She is married to Jérôme, a store keeper. Together they have five children, of whom three are students. 

The Kiva loan of 300,000 Burundi francs that Anastasie obtained has enabled her to increase her capital to buy large amounts of various goods (beans, rice, sugar, soaps, cookies, palm oil...) to resell, so as to make a large profit. 

She is a member of the community group "Yagamahoro".

loans.use: to increase her capital to buy large amounts of various shop goods (beans, rice, sugar, soaps, cookies, palm oil...) to resell in order to make a large profit

loans.name: Vumilia Shg Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Vumilia SHG Group in Western Kenya! Josephat is the facilitator of the Vumilia SHG group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Josephat is a father of five children. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough to feed his family and access fertilizer and hybrid seeds to ensure food security. In the recent 2011 season, Josephat had an excellent maize yield harvesting 16 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Josephat was only able to harvest three bags of maize on one acre of land.
